missionSuccessStatementOverride: Good job Commander. My team is securing the facility as we speak. Lets debrief later today.
shortDescription:
We suspect that the ancient SDLF bunker we are searching for is located beneath the even older Norilsk-11 mine, situated near the northern pole, far from cities.

Unfortunately, a bandit gang known as the Morenci Gang has seized control of the area. We need you to reclaim the mine courtyard and secure its perimeter before we deploy the CQB specialists.
longDescription: Commander, we have detected both turret emplacements and several huge 'Mech signatures. Deploy maximum firepower.

objectiveList.title: Secure the Area Around the Norilsk-11
objectiveList.description: This is a general objective to indicate the player must keep playing and eliminate enemies as they come.

dialogueContent.words: I couldn't drop the lance any closer, Commander. I was painted by an AD radar the moment I dropped below 32K.
You did well Sumire... Commander, your team stands just beyond the valley where the Norilsk-11 mine is situated.
Advance on the mine, eliminate defenders, but exercise caution due to turret emplacements.
Once you have control over the courtyard, I will deploy with mine CQB specialists to secure the facility.
Your own Dr. Murad has insisted on joining our team.
Well done, Commander; Seems like you have disabled all auto-turrets
Well done, Commander; the mine is now under our control. My men will proceed with stage 2, securing the facility itself.
For an ancient mine, this place was awfully well-guarded. I'm pulling the plug, Commander.
Area not cleared, Commander. Eliminate all hostiles so Rasalhague infantry can land.
Enemy forces eliminated - secure the mine.
<color=#FF7F7F>Guys....We need you here...I see some freaking huge mechs on radar!</color>
<color=#FF7F7F>Boss, we're about to die over here!</color>
<color=#FF7F7F>Then keep on dying - but keep this line clear!</color>
This place is no 300 year old ruin! It seems like it has recently undergone renovations and upgrades.
